prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO/HCN/HC3N/H13CN/HC15N/C2H5CN/CH3CCCN/C2H3CN/HC5N/winds
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Tuning 1 of 3. We will observe the atmosphere of Titan at 0.14" resolution (configuration C36-5), obtaining spectral line observations of many species.
In this tuning we center the primary LO near 350 GHz in order to target specral lines of: CO, HCN, HC3N, H13CN, HC15N, HC3N(v7=1)+CH3OH, C2H3CN
The observations will include broad line wing coverage (CO and HCN) as well as high spectral resolution (70 kHz) on line cores of HC3N and HCN for wind measurements.
We estimate total on source time is ~50 min, requiring 1.5 hours total array time including calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral binning has been carefully chosen to limit the average data rate below 12 MB/s. The correlator setup maximizes coverage of both broad line wings and narrow line core coverage for abundance and wind retrieval. Details are:
BB# Split Center(GHz) BW(MHz) Res(kHz) Lines; motivation for observation
1 1/2 354.69756 58.6 70.6 HC3N; abundance+winds 1 1/2 354.50547 58.6 70.6 HCN line core; thermospheric temperature+winds
2 1 355.19000 1875.0 1129.0 HCN line wing, HC3N, C2H5CN, HCN-v2, CH3CCCN, C2H3CN; detection+abundance
3 1 343.20000 1875.0 1129.0 CO line wing, CS, CH3CCCN, C2H5CN, C2H3CN; detection+abundance
4 1 345.00000 1875.0 1129.0 CO center, H-13CN, HC3N, HC-15N, HC5N; detection+abundance

Titan has a diameter of 5150 km = 0.8" during 2016.
The 0.14" spatial resolution is carefully chosen to equal a horizontal/linear resolution of 900 km at Titan, which provides separation of latitudes poleward of 80 degrees from the lower latitudes and allows investigation of the polar enhancements seen by CIRS (see Figure 4). This is also roughly the maximum extent of the atmosphere we can sense in the strongest lines like HCN, and close to the height of the 2016 Cassini close flybys.
This will provide a 6x6 map of Titan's continuum and lower atmosphere. We note that Titan will be well-positioned at night during the expected schedule of configuration C36-5 which is a near perfect match for our science requirements.

5.1 mJy rms for this tuning is chosen to obtain high SNR at 250 kHz resolution on strong lines (SNR between 18 and 42 for CO, HCN, HC3N) for accurate abundance retrieval. 250 kHz resolves the mean FWHM of most spectral lines in Titan's upper atmosphere into a few resolution elements, enough for accurate abundance retrieval.
Furthermore, this sensitivity translates to 9.5 mJy rms at 70 kHz resolution which we use for direct wind determination via doppler shift measurement of line cores. The narrow cores have peak flux density relative to their broader component of 50 to 100 mJy/beam at 0.14" resolution for HC3N and HCN, leading to SNR of 5-10 on the core. Based on our previous Titan wind measurements in the mm/submm (Moreno et al 2005, Gurwell et al 2009), we estimate that an SNR between 5-10 with at 70 KHz is needed to obtain wind accuracy of 10-20 m/s on the strong lines. Since the expected winds lie between 100-200 m/s, we will get SNR ~ 10 on the wind velocity for the strongest narrow lines of HCN and HC3N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CH3CN/HNC/DCN/C2H5CN/CH3OH/CH3CCCN/C2H3CN/winds
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Tuning 2 of 3. We will observe the atmosphere of Titan at 0.14" resolution (configuration C36-5), obtaining spectral line observations of many species.
In this tuning we center the primary LO near 356 GHz in order to target specral lines of: CH3CN, HNC, DCN, HCCC15N, C2H5CN+CH3OH, H2CO, C2N2, C2H3CN
The observations will include broad line wing coverage CH3CN as well as high spectral resolution (70 kHz) on line cores of CH3CN, HNC, and DCN for wind measurements.
We estimate total on source time is ~50 min, requiring 1.5 hours total array time including calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral binning has been carefully chosen to limit the average data rate below 12 MB/s. The correlator setup maximizes coverage of both broad line wings and narrow line core coverage for abundance and wind retrieval. Details are:
BB# Split Center(GHz) BW(MHz) Res(kHz) Lines; motivation for observation
1 1 349.39332 468.7 282.2 CH3CN, C2H5CN; detection+abundance
2 1/2 349.447 58.6 70.6 CH3CN strongest line cores, C2H5CN; winds+detection+abundance
3 1/2 362.04574 58.6 70.6 DCN; winds+abundance 3 1/2 362.63030 58.6 70.6 HNC; winds+abundance
4 1 362.88300 1875.0 1129.0 HNC,DCN,CH3CCCN,C2H5CN,C2H3CN,HC3N; detection+abundance

Titan has a diameter of 5150 km = 0.8" during 2016.
The 0.14" spatial resolution is carefully chosen to equal a horizontal/linear resolution of 900 km at Titan, which provides separation of latitudes poleward of 80 degrees from the lower latitudes and allows investigation of the polar enhancements seen by CIRS (see Figure 4). This is also roughly the maximum extent of the atmosphere we can sense in the strongest lines like HCN, and close to the height of the 2016 Cassini close flybys.
This will provide a 6x6 map of Titan's continuum and lower atmosphere. We note that Titan will be well-positioned at night during the expected schedule of configuration C36-5 which is a near perfect match for our science requirements.

6.1 mJy rms for this tuning is chosen to obtain high SNR at 250 kHz resolution on strong lines (SNR up to ~20 for CH3CN) for accurate abundance retrieval. 250 kHz resolves the mean FWHM of most spectral lines in Titan's upper atmosphere into a few resolution elements, enough for accurate abundance retrieval.
Furthermore, this sensitivity translates to 10.5 mJy rms at 70 kHz resolution which we use for direct wind determination via doppler shift measurement of line cores of CH3CN. The narrow cores have peak flux density relative to their broader component of 50 to 100 mJy/beam at 0.14" resolution leading to SNR of 5-10 on the core. Based on our previous Titan wind measurements in the mm/submm (Moreno et al 2005, Gurwell et al 2009), we estimate that an SNR between 5-10 with at 70 KHz is needed to obtain wind accuracy of 10-20 m/s on the strong lines. Since the expected winds lie between 100-200 m/s, we will get SNR ~ 10 on the wind velocity for the strongest narrow lines of CH3CN.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CH3CCH/CH3OH/13CO/C18O/C2H3CN/C2H5CN/CH2NH/CH3CCCN/CH3CN
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Tuning 3 of 3. We will observe the atmosphere of Titan at 0.14" resolution (configuration C36-5), obtaining spectral line observations of many species.
In this tuning we center the primary LO near 336.8 GHz in order to target specral lines of: CH3CCH, 13CO, C18O, CH3CN, C2H5CN+CH3OH, CH2NH, C2H3CN
The observations will include broad line coverage for CO isotopes,CH3CN, and many other species as well as moderate spectral resolution (282 kHz) on the CH3CCH k-ladders.
We estimate total on source time is ~50 min, requiring 1.5 hours total array time including calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral binning has been carefully chosen to limit the average data rate below 12 MB/s. The correlator setup maximizes coverage of both broad line wings and narrow line core coverage for abundance retrieval. Details are:
BB# Split Center(GHz) BW(MHz) Res(kHz) Lines; motivation for observation
1 1 330.00000 1875.0 1129.0 13CO,C-18O, HC5N, CH3CCCN, C2H5CN,C2H3CN; detection+abundance
2 1 331.80000 1875.0 1129.0 CH3CN, C2H5CN, C2N2, CH2NH; detection+abundance
3 1 341.68247 468.7 282.2 CH3CCH, C2H5CN, CH3NC; detection+abundance
4 1 342.72983 937.5 970.0 CH3CCCN, CS, C2H3CN; detection+abundance

Titan has a diameter of 5150 km = 0.8" during 2016.
The 0.14" spatial resolution is carefully chosen to equal a horizontal/linear resolution of 900 km at Titan, which provides separation of latitudes poleward of 80 degrees from the lower latitudes and allows investigation of the polar enhancements seen by CIRS (see Figure 4). This is also roughly the maximum extent of the atmosphere we can sense in the strongest lines like HCN, and close to the height of the 2016 Cassini close flybys.
This will provide a 6x6 map of Titan's continuum and lower atmosphere. We note that Titan will be well-positioned at night during the expected schedule of configuration C36-5 which is a near perfect match for our science requirements.

2.60 mJy rms for this tuning is chosen to obtain moderate SNR at 1 MHz resolution allowing search for many expected but previously undetected species. It will provide good SNR (10-15) on CO isotopes and >20 on CH3CN for accurate abundance and isotopic ratio retrieval. 1 MHz is a good compromise between providing broad bandwidth to cover multiple lines, with a resolution that does not smooth the lines too much (resolution ~ line FWHM).
Higher resoluton is placed on the CH3C2H baseband, which (at 282 kHz resolution) will only obtain SNR ~ 3-4 per channel, but more when integrated. The higher resolution is necessary to distinguish the CH3C2H lines from C2H5CN (previously detected) and C2H3CN lines (previously undetected).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to conduct a detailed characterization of the thermal, chemical, and dynamical state of Titan's atmosphere near southern winter solstice. Using three Band 7 tunings at 0.14" resolution we propose to:
* determine vertical and latitudinal distributions of all known compounds detected at submm wavelengths
* constrain overall dynamics using distributions of trace species while directly measuring zonal+meridional wind components from 300 to 900 km altitude
* determine thermospheric temperatures at 600-900 km altitude using HCN hyperfine components and independently using CO and HC3N
* determine precise isotopic ratios in CO, HCN and other nitriles
* investigate changes occurring in the south polar region, including dramatic enrichments in many constituents and potential detection of new molecules, isomers, and isotopologues.
These observations will come towards the end of the Cassini Solstice Mission and will provide important and unique cross-calibration checks between Cassini and ALMA measurements. Ultimately this will allow ALMA to expand, improve upon, and extend the rich legacy of Titan atmospheric studies through an entire Titan year.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00064.S - Exploring the nitrile and oxygen chemistry in Titan's middle atmosphere (PI: S. Vinatier) 2011.0.00727.S - Mapping the nitrile chemistry and dynamics of Titan's thermosphere (PI: Moreno)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy and Bosscha Observatory, Institut Teknologi Bandung
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
